title: Car tax hike: How much you'll pay when VED increases from April 1
text:
Motorists are set to be hit with a stealth rise in car tax from this month that could see annual costs rise by as much as £65 for the hardest hit drivers.

The hike - though not mentioned during the Chancellor's autumn or spring statement - was confirmed as part of last year's Budget document, stating that Vehicle and Excise Duty (VED) rates would increase in line with inflation from 1 April 2019.

For buyers of new cars this could mean an increase in first year VED rates of up to £65. And many drivers with older cars could also be stung, with some having to fork out an extra £15 a year.

To help you find out how much extra you'll be paying, we've created a selection of handy tools so you can see if your car tax costs will jump this month.

Stealth car tax hike: Use our tools to work out how much extra you'll be paying in VED from April 1

My car was registered after 1 April 2017

Cars with number plates featuring: 17 (registered after April 1 2017), 67, 18, 68, 19

The Government opted to revamp VED rates in April 2017.

'First year tax' (only paid the first year you buy a brand new car) has a scaled rate based on how much CO2 emissions your car produces.

The 'standard rate tax' - paid from the second year onwards - is different. Now it is a flat rate scheme for all but zero-emissions electric cars (which are exempt).

This flat rate is £140 (£130 for hybrid cars) a year. That means it nullifies whether your vehicle has low CO2 emissions or not.

It means owners of the an economical Ford Fiesta has to pay the same in car tax as someone who purchases a 5.0-litre petrol-guzzling Mustang V8 after the second year.

As of April 1 there will be changes to both the first year rates and the standard ones.

For owners of electric and some hybrid cars, first year rates will be unchanged.

However, those with petrol and diesel models producing more than 90 grams per kilometre of CO2 (which is all of them), the smallest increase will be £5 for the first year.

For those with high emissions cars with big thirsty engines, first year tax could rise by as much as £65.

The standard rate increase is just £5 a year - increasing to £145 for petrol and diesel models and £135 for hybrids. Pure electric cars remain free.

Last year's standard rate also came with an 'additional' premium rate for all cars - even electric models - with a list price of £40,000 or more.

This additional rate added another £310 onto the standard rate of tax for five years.

That rate will also increase from April, going up to £320.

If your car was registered after 1 April 2017, use the tool below to find out how much extra in VED you'll be paying in 2019.

My car was registered between 1 March 2001 and 31 March 2017

Cars with number plates featuring: Y,51, 02, 52, 03, 53, 04, 54, 05, 55, 06, 56, 07, 57, 08, 58, 09, 59, 10, 60, 11, 61, 12, 62, 13, 63, 14, 64, 15, 65, 16, 66, 17 (registered in March 2017)

If your car was registered between March 2001 and the end of March 2017 you're also likely to have to pay more VED from April 1.

Vehicles with the lowest CO2 outputs - less than 120g/km - won't have to pay any extra.

However, anyone with a car emitting more than 121g/km CO2 will have to pay between £5 and £15 a year more.

Use the tool below to find out how much extra in VED you'll be paying if your car is around 2 and 17 years old.

If you're unable to see the tool in the MailOnline app please click on this link to view it on our website instead.

My car was registered before 1 March 2001

Cars with pre-Y-reg number plates

The Driver and Vehicle Licencing Agency (DVSA) exclusively confirmed to This is Money that owners of cars registered before 1 March 2001 will also have to pay more car tax each year from April 1 2019.

This will depend on the engine size of your car.

For those with vehicles with engines larger than 1.55 litres, VED has increased £10 to £265 a year, while owners of cars with smaller engines will see their annual tax go up by £5.

Use the tool below to find out how much you tax is going to increase if you have a car registered before March 2001.

If you're unable to see the tool in the MailOnline app please click on this link to view it on our website instead.

My car is more than 40 years old

If your car is more than 40 years old it will be exempt from VED.

However, you do need to apply through the DVLA to register your vehicle to be free from car tax.
